channel.title: 637 Dialog Creator/Generator - Simple to use!
channel.description:
Hey guys, i'm not to sure if anyone will really use this as I have not seen much 637 developers lately. But, I made this for my personal use while creating my server and let go of RSPS creating, so I mine as well release the tool I was using for anyone who may be looking for this in the future. I hope people use it, because it did take some time to make it, so I hope you guys like it!

A standalone dialogue system would probably work fine.

item.title: 637 Dialog Creator/Generator - Simple to use!
item.dc:creator: @sk8rdude461 sk8rdude461
item.description:
@sk8rdude461 wrote:

This looks like too much work for what you’re trying to accomplish.
I do like the idea. But how you’re going about it, not so much.

You should make a system (yes, an entire system) that would save all the dialogues to an external file (like JSON), maybe even have a folder for it…
Lets say you’re going to have a “dialogues” folder. Now in that folder, would be some odd amount of JSON files. Each file would be for one NPC or one NPC group (because sometimes you have multiple NPCs with the same name but diff IDs). And in each JSON file, would be all the dialogues for the npc(s). You could make an object for all the dialogues in a scene. Example:
(Remember this is an example, not working code rofl)

{ "npcs": [ 0, 1, 2 ], "dialogues": [ { "systemid": 0, "dialogueid": 0, "expression": "HAPPY" "phrases": [ "Talking", "about", "the", "quest", "here" ], "nextdialogue": 1 }, { "systemid": 0, "dialogueid": 1, "expression": "ANGRY" "phrases": [ "More", "about", "the", "quest", "here" ], "nextdialogue": 2 }, ] }
Of course I haven’t added all possible data in the example. Because it’s a damn example.

But here’s an explanation of the data you’re reading (most if not all is obvious):
[font=Verdana] “systemid”: The ID of the dialogues in the server. This would be used to dictate what dialogue to pull up. Ex: getNextDialogue(SystemId), and then it’d return the next dialogue that had the same systemid, but the next dialogueid…[/font][font=Verdana] “dialogueid”: The ID of the dialogue in that particular set of dialogues. “expression”: The expression your the entity would be displaying in the dialogue window. “phrases”: Obviously the data that is in dialogue window. You’ll need some form of content control here ( like no more than 5 lines of text and only X amount of characters per line). “nextdialogue”: The next ID in that particular set of dialogues.

[font=verdana, arial, helvetica, sans-serif]I hope this (rather half assed and quickly thought up/sketched out) concept helps you in the future…[/font]

[/font]

Read full topic

item.title: 637 Dialog Creator/Generator - Simple to use!
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:5, topic:546843”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=665741.msg4450714#msg4450714 date=1411157006]

Hope you don’t think your funny or anything because your highly mistaken. Otherwise, sure why not.

You made an application to output code. Really crap too. Maybe if you app implemented the dialogue too then it could be notable. You’re not decreasing the time at all for adding dialogues.

Why is this good?
[/quote]
Piss off.[/quote]
Erm no, it’s much faster to copy an exisitng case and edit it through that instead of having to open up this and have to keep typing the same things over again.

Read full topic

item.title: 637 Dialog Creator/Generator - Simple to use!
item.dc:creator: @tyb97 tyb97
item.description:
@tyb97 wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:4, topic:546843”][quote author=im4ever12c link=topic=665741.msg4450708#msg4450708 date=1411155136]
Hope you don’t think your funny or anything because your highly mistaken. Otherwise, sure why not.
[/quote]
You made an application to output code. Really crap too. Maybe if you app implemented the dialogue too then it could be notable. You’re not decreasing the time at all for adding dialogues.

Why is this good?[/quote]
Piss off.

@OP, You should release this as open-source, not many people will use it for what it was made for, as it really isn’t efficient considering the correct solution is a plugin based dialogue system anyways. Uploading the source code to a remote like Github will help create a better learning environment for everybody, as your code can be used for learning and references.

Read full topic
